article.text: WILLIAM Hague says Britain will push for "strong international response" A graphic video showed blood-drenched bodies of at least 32 youngsters under ten who had been hacked or shot to death. They were among 116 civilian victims of a massacre in the town of Houla carried out by forces loyal to President Assad. Britain led the outrage — with Foreign Secretary William Hague demanding a “strong international response” after the “stomach-churning” pictures were US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said Assad’s “rule by murder and fear must come to an end”. The UN Security Council said after an emergency meeting last night that it condemned the killings “in strongest possible terms”. Syria’s ally Russia said the “tragic” events deserved condemnation and called for a UN assessment of the violence. Syrian opposition activist Maysara al-Hilawi told how he saw the bodies of six children and their parents in a ransacked house in Houla. He said: “The children’s corpses were piled on top of each other, with their throats cut or shot at close range. “I helped collect more than 100 bodies in the last two days, mostly women and children. The last were six members of one family — a father and his five kids. The mother is missing.” About 300 civilians were injured in Friday’s carnage — one of the worst atrocities in the 14-month revolt against the Assad regime which has cost Outrage ... protester Activists said tanks, mortars and machine guns fired on civilians after demonstrations. Then Assad’s militia is said to have launched the massacre. Russia had said it was sceptical that the Syrian regime was behind the Assad’s foreign ministry blamed “terrorists” and said: “This is not the hallmark of the heroic Syrian army.” Mr Hague will meet Russia’s foreign secretary in Moscow today. Syria’s ambassador to Britain faces a diplomatic dressing down.
